There are several different commercially available techniques for providing z-axis or depth information. They include traditional stereo cameras with two lenses, as well as more advanced approaches using structured light or time-of-flight. Each has its own strengths and weakness, including the physical size of the module, accuracy of the depth information, the ability to provide depth information in different lighting conditions, and of course cost. Today, thanks to advanced signal processing, 3D cameras are able to interpret and represent 3D imagery even better than humans, enabling some pretty compelling applications–including biometric security.
